fields.description: Filter the launch configurations table using visual search bar. Wireframe is available at https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Manage+Launch+Configurations+Landing
fields.summary: launch configurations landing table filtering with magic search bar

comments.body:
All text search is there and works.  Looking at the wireframe, it appears that the other two facets should be "Root Device" and "OS".  However, neither of these - nor anything that resembles them - is part of the data that's provided as part of the autoscaling?Action=DescribeLaunchConfigurations call.

I imagine we could take the ID of the AMI and iterate all of the available ones and figure this out;  or perhaps there's some other way to get it included in the data from the server.  Not sure what the Right Thing is here.  For now, leaving the set of facets as 

['all_text', 'name', 'spot_price', 'instance_type']

pending resolution of this.

Please help finish these up, Tim couldn't figure out this. He asks: "review the facets stuff - if you know the right property names it's dead-simple and pretty self-explanatory to tweak them - it's just an array of names that should be facets, and a mapping to human-friendly names." 

You know the data inside out. For existing resources the facets are the same as what we used to filter on via pull downs.
This one needs root_device_type and platform from the linked image_id.

I've got this implemented, with a couple of caveats - Ean, can you help out with the last bit of this?

I'm looking up app.data.images, and building a lookup table by id, to cross reference the image id with the image's platform and root_device_type, to populate these properties.  Two bits of trouble with Backbone I'm running into:

1.  Introspecting app.data.images, it has contents, but toJSON() returns an empty array, so the lookup table is always empty
2.  Not clear how to trigger updating the lookup table if the data changes out from under things

Or, perhaps there is such a lookup table already available somewhere, so as to avoid having this little cache at all?  We need something, since I don't thing iterating launchConfigurationCount * imageCount right when a popup is being populated would be a great idea.

[~tboudreau] If you type @ right before tying someone's name you can pick them from a list and they will get notified via email that you are talking to them here. Like hey [~eans] did you see [~tboudreau] pinged you in the comment above this one? :)

Instance type values need to say "m1.small" instead of just "small" (there can be more than one type of "mdeium" for example so we need to be specific), OS and Root Device Type not giving any values when selected. Kicking back to In Progress.

For the instance types, we should not hard code the names in here. Those are defined by the CLC and theoretically could change. Can we simply allow instance_type to be a facet without giving a bunch of possible values? (or draw from the values actually in the table data?)

Does that mean the list of instance types on the instances page should also be changed (see the list of types in the wireframe - that's what I used here)? 

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/wiki/display/3UD/Manage+Instances+Landing

the instance types in the wireframes match a filter in AWS. If we can filter down specifically to things like m1.small for example that would be even better. [~tboudreau] if you can confirm that's possible and go ahead and get things started on your end, I'll update the wireframes.

So, if you really want stuff like "high memory" in there, I can see how Amazon would do that. Their  vmtypes don't change as a rule. In Eucalyptus, we allow our uses to change, at least the parameters of the types. In future releases, we'll allow them to change the types as well (add/remove).
I would recommend that if we try to mimic the categories of instances that amazon is using, we base it on ranges of values in the vmtype definitions. That still won't be easy to communicate to users though. Thoughts?

I can just modify the default behavior localize() (which replaces _ and - with spaces and titlecases names *if* no actual localized name is supplied) to replace . with ' ' too, so that it will generate "M1 Small" from "m1.small" and that will take care of it - *but* the text will always be a munged version of the literal text from the server.

But you will have to give up on things like "High Memory" from the wireframe above.  Is that ok?
Okay, I just pushed a change which does as described above - if it see "t1.micro" it will get translated by default to "T1 Micro" in the UI.  "High Memory" and such from the wireframes are gone.
OS and Root Device Type still not giving any values when selected. Kicking back to In Progress.

Hrm, it looks like there simply are no fields for OS or root device in the list of launch configurations.  I'll try cross-referencing it with the list of images.  

However, in the mock data, the image_id field does not actually correspond to anything in the image list.  I'll modify the mock data locally to test it.
I just pushed 22fcb60126f478e095ce7e2bb6bbd74588fe45c3 to team/console/3.3 - which fixes the facet list.
